title: How to Help with Math Homework You Don't Understand
description: Practical strategies for supporting your child when the math is beyond your knowledge.
imageAlt: Parent looking at confusing math problem

content.intro: Your middle schooler asks for help with algebra and you don't remember any of it. Or the "new math" makes no sense to you. Here's how to help anyway.

sections.text: You Don't Need to Be the Expert
Your job isn't to teach the math. Your job is to:
"What did your teacher show you?" "Read me the directions." "What do you remember about this type of problem?" Help them access their own knowledge first.
2. Look at Class Notes and Examples
Check the textbook, notebook, or online class materials for worked examples. The answer is often there.

items: Khan Academy (free video lessons on every topic)
Photomath (takes picture of problem, shows steps)

sections.text: "I don't remember this either – let's figure it out together." This models lifelong learning and problem-solving.
After reasonable effort, write a note to the teacher explaining what you tried. It's better than frustration, tears, or doing it for them.
"I don't know how to do this, but I know we can figure it out" is more powerful than either "I can't help you" or pretending to know.
Questions That Help Without Knowing the Math

items: "Have you done a problem like this before?"
Don't pretend to understand when you don't
Don't get frustrated visibly (they'll absorb it)
Don't give up immediately ("ask your teacher")
Don't do the problem for them using Google

faq.question: Should I feel bad that I can't help?
faq.answer: No. Math education has changed, and most parents hit a point where they can't help directly. Your support, attitude, and resourcefulness matter more than your math knowledge.

faq.question: What if my child gets frustrated when I don't know?
faq.answer: Stay calm. "I know this is frustrating. Let's take a break and try again, or we can ask your teacher tomorrow." Your emotional steadiness matters.

faq.question: Should I learn the math to help?
faq.answer: If you have time and interest, yes – it's good modeling. But it's not required. Your role is supporter, not math teacher.
